docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Rising medical malpractice insurance premiums are causing hospitals to close obstetric wards; trauma centers to shut their doors; and doctors to drop services, move to more doctor-friendly states, order more expensive tests or retire early (front page, Aug. 25).
docs.abstract: Sen Bill Frist letter on Aug 25 article urges Congress to cap lawyers' contingency fees for medical malpractice claims; holds rising medical malpractice premiums are limiting access to care
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    Rising medical malpractice insurance premiums are causing hospitals to close obstetric wards; trauma centers to shut their doors; and doctors to drop services, move to more doctor-friendly states, order more expensive tests or...

docs.lead_paragraph: A venture by seven big health insurers to take control of electronic services that link them with patients and doctors has run into financial trouble, industry officials said, and most of the companies have written down all or most of their investment in the effort. Insurance companies expect to reap enormous savings if they can persuade hundreds of thousands of doctors to use computers and the Internet instead of telephones and paper to submit claims for reimbursement, check on patients' coverage and obtain routine approvals for tests and referrals to specialists.

headline.main: Health Insurers Still Struggling With a Service On the Internet

docs.abstract: Five of original seven major health insurers that founded MedUnite, Internet service they hoped hundreds of thousands of doctors would use in place of telephones and paper for clerical claims needs, have written down all or most of their investments in service; MedUnite has been slow to catch on, and seeks further financing; it competes with WebMD, which operates at a loss (M)
docs.snippet: A venture by seven big health insurers to take control of electronic services that link them with patients and doctors has run into financial trouble, industry officials said, and most of the companies have written down all or most of their...

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Veterans' Health System,'' by Anthony J. Principi, secretary of veterans affairs (letter, Aug. 24):
docs.abstract: Dr David L Oshin reply to Sec Anthony J Principi's Aug 24 letter proposes offering eligible veterans prescription benefits without requiring them to seek other Veterans Administration health services if they are privately insured or eligible for Medicare but lack drug coverage
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    Re ''Veterans' Health System,'' by Anthony J. Principi, secretary of veterans affairs (letter, Aug. 24):

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: As ''Debate Grows on Jury's Role in Injury Cases'' shows (front page, Aug. 26), the civil jury system, which has served and protected us so well for more than 200 years, is today an embattled and vulnerable institution.
docs.abstract: Center for Justice and Democracy official Joanne Doroshow letter on Aug 26 article defends civil jury system, holding it is under attack by corporate wrongdoers and their insurers to limit liability exposure, including punitive damage awards
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    As ''Debate Grows on Jury's Role in Injury Cases'' shows (front page, Aug. 26), the civil jury system, which has served and protected us so well for more than 200 years, is today an embattled and vulnerable institution.

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-15 Administration Debates Course of Action Over Iraq Senior administration officials expect that President Bush will eventually seek some new explicit sign of approval from Congress, but not necessarily a formal vote, before launching any military campaign against Iraq. Meanwhile, there is debate over involving the United Nations again to bolster the case against Saddam Hussein. A1 Saudi Public Relations The Saudi Arabian government is spending millions to counter intensified anger or skepticism among Americans toward their country, which was home to 15 of the 19 Sept. 11th hijackers and has clashed publicly with the Bush administration over a possible attack against Iraq. A1

docs.lead_paragraph: Gov. Ronnie Musgrove urged lawmakers to limit noneconomic damages in medical malpractice cases to $250,000 for doctors who treat Medicaid patients and join a proposed state-run malpractice liability insurance plan. Damages would be limited to $500,000 for all other doctors and health providers. Governor Murgrove also urged lawmakers to stem the mass tort cases against drug makers by prohibiting out-of-state patients from suing in Mississippi courts.

headline.main: National Briefing | South: Mississippi: Governor's Malpractice Plan

docs.abstract: Gov Ronnie Musgrove urges Mississippi lawmakers to limit noneconomic damages in medical malpractice cases to $250,000 for doctors who treat Medicaid patients and join proposed state-run malpractice liability insurance plan; damages would be limited to $500,000 for all other doctors and health providers; Musgrove also seek ban on suits against drug makers by out-of-state patients (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: ''WE need the pink stuff,'' said a hoarse voice from the other side of the screen door. From inside the cabin, I could see the tops of two little heads, one with a ponytail and both with desperate dark eyes. ''Please,'' whispered Clementine, my 4-year-old.

headline.main: Rx for a Big Move: Refills on the Web

docs.abstract: Michelle Slatalla Online Shopper column tries refilling prescriptions at several Web sites; finds database at Walgreens.com is completely integrated with bricks-and-mortar store making refilling process relatively seamless; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In a free-form radio debate yesterday between the two candidates seeking the Democratic nomination for governor, Andrew M. Cuomo accused H. Carl McCall of failing to block an unrealistic state budget and of stopping short of calling for the outright repeal of the Rockefeller drug laws. Mr. McCall insisted he had no power to force a better fiscal plan and said his differences with Mr. Cuomo over the drug laws were merely semantic.

headline.main: Cuomo and McCall Debate Drug Law Proposals and Talk Up Their Résumés

docs.abstract: New York gubernatorial rivals Andrew Cuomo and H Carl McCall hold free-form radio debate in which they exchange opinions and allegations on fiscal policy and drug laws, and promote their own records (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The use of hand-held devices in health care (''For the Doctor's Touch, Help in the Hand,'' Aug. 22) is regulated by the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act of 1996. Doctors who store patient information on such devices must implement safeguards that comply with the act's strict security and privacy standards aimed at protecting patients' medical information from inappropriate use or disclosure. Failure to comply can result in criminal and civil penalties.
docs.abstract: Dan Jacob letter on August 22 article notes doctors must, by law, safeguard patient information stored in hand-held devices
